awd_titl_txt: Phase II IUCRC University of Louisville: Center for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT)
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Louisville (UL) applies to become a Phase II research site addition for the NSF Industry-University Cooperative Research Center (IUCRC) for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT). The American health care delivery system falls short of care that is safe, effective, patient-centered, timely, and equitable. Health care organizations are continually innovating in both management and clinical practices to address care efficiency shortcomings, offer the latest clinical technologies, and remain competitive. To attain significant progress on all of these fronts requires transformational changes in health organizations that fundamentally alter practices and culture, and lead to better health care. UL CHOT applies and refines a comprehensive transformation framework that will guide, research, and advance organization transformation in health systems, especially hospitals, clinics, and physician groups. With health spending rising exponentially, government, industry, and the public share growing concerns about a range of health care issues related to the organization and payment for health care services. New care models also require a shift in the types of clinicians that staff healthcare organizations. UL CHOT is committed to conducting research to understand what the optimal mix of these new services will be under new value-based ways of providing healthcare for the benefit of a diverse patient population. 

UL CHOT's multi-disciplinary research team proposes to join the existing CHOT university sites, adding value through its in-depth integration of expertise in population health management, health information system design, and health systems sciences that will create new synergies that allows the research to be highly relevant, and incorporate best practices and the latest technology. UL CHOT will conduct mixed-methodology, applied research on the antecedents, execution, and effects of transformational interventions and strategies that combine evidence-based management, clinical and information technology innovations, and ongoing organizational learning and cultural change. Transformational efforts in health systems frequently ignore or prematurely treat several individual and organizational elements as "fixed" or immutable. Transformational strategies call for significant reexamination and, often, realignment of values, processes, and structures characterizing a health system. Such major innovations (i.e., LEAN, cutting-edge clinical innovations and information systems) call for leadership, significant cultural change, inter-professional alignment, elements of process reengineering, and effective monitoring and feedback. Our industry-guided research program identifies the factors that produce desired results from these kinds of transformational interventions in health systems. UL CHOT will contribute significantly to the efficiency and quality of care offered by industry partners by enabling more effective implementation of the aforementioned tools and strategies.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Center for Health Organization Transformation (CHOT) launched in 2008 as a partnership between Texas A & M University and Georgia Tech. In 2016 and 2017, Penn State University, University of Alabama at Birmingham, University of Washington, University of Nottingham (internal affiliate), Florida Atlantic University, and University of Louisville joined as affiliate sites. The mission of CHOT was to advance knowledge and practice of transformational strategies in evidence-based management, information technology, clinical practice, and organizational learning through collaborative research between academic and industry partners. 

Since its inception, CHOT has engaged with more than 25 industry partners to conduct a broad range of health and healthcare research. Our industry partners have been diverse and included large healthcare systems, insurers, non-profits, and long-term care facilities. In the five years that University of Louisville (UofL) participated as a CHOT university site, we engaged twelve industry partners, totaling nearly $1.1 million in research contributions. Some examples of past research projects led by the University of Louisville UofL include working with a national philanthropic foundation to identify data-driven strategies to support their investments in community financial well-being, supporting a large healthcare system to better understand the reach and use of primary care services offered in their satellite neighborhood clinics, and exploring factors related to the intersection of work culture, mental health, and well-being. Moreover, students were an important partner stakeholder in conducting research within the Center. The UofL site trained and graduated four five masters and doctoral level students who are now serving as faculty members healthcare administrators, at other institutions or pursuing an advanced degree, or working as a university faculty member. We additionally trained three four doctoral students, one of whom has graduated and is now a faculty member at a university, and the others who are nearing the end of their PhD studies. UofL CHOT faculty and student research assistants have produced more than 80 combined peer-reviewed publications, oral and poster presentations, and non-peer reviewed reports that have been disseminated in local and national outlets. 

 CHOT served as a convener and vehicle for transformational research by bringing together industry partners and academic researchers to use rigorous research methodologies to address key challenges facing healthcare and communities across the country. Most recently, in Spring 2022, CHOT convened its industry and university partners in Louisville, Kentucky for an its final in-person meeting, designed to expand our existing research partnerships to new areas such as artificial intelligence and learn from one another about existing work.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2023
Modified by: Christopher E Johnson

Since its inception, CHOT has engaged with more than 25 industry partners to conduct a broad range of health and healthcare research. Our industry partners have been diverse and included large healthcare systems, insurers, non-profits, and long-term care facilities. In the five years that University of Louisville (UofL) participated as a CHOT university site, we engaged twelve industry partners, totaling nearly $1.1 million in research contributions.  CHOT served as a convener and vehicle for transformational research by bringing together industry partners and academic researchers to use rigorous research methodologies to address key challenges facing healthcare and communities across the country.
